[{"question":"Explain the support provided for FAC aircrew during acceptance check flights, including maintenance crew requirements.","section":"Acceptance Check Flight","response":"Field Aerospace has established comprehensive support for FAC aircrew during acceptance check flights, ensuring all maintenance and operational requirements are met to facilitate safe and effective flight operations. The company provides qualified aircrew with the best qualifications as determined by command directives and flying unit commanders to conduct acceptance check flights under appropriate visual meteorological conditions. Maintenance crew requirements include the presence of a knowledgeable aircraft crew chief or representative and quality assurance personnel to attend pre-flight briefings and verify compliance with maintenance standards. Field Aerospace adheres to rigorous quality assurance protocols, including AS9100D and ISO 10012 standards, to ensure all aircraft systems are fully functional and documented prior to flight. The company maintains detailed documentation and certification packages, including STC reports and inspection procedures, to support aircrew and maintenance teams during acceptance check flights. This structured approach ensures that all modifications and maintenance actions are verified, and the aircraft is configured correctly for flight, thereby supporting mission readiness and safety.","type":"Technical Written Response"}]

[{"question":"Describe the process for returning equipment items removed from the aircraft, tagging, and disposal of other materials.","section":"Equipment Disposal","response":"Field Aerospace has a comprehensive process for returning equipment items removed from aircraft, tagging, and disposal of other materials. All inventoried equipment is tracked and stored securely in accordance with Government Furnished Property (GFP) procedures. Field Aerospace ensures controlled receipt and identification of Government equipment and tooling using approved processes, including human-readable stamps, tags, or barcode tags to indicate Government ownership, maintaining stewardship records for traceability. Removed parts facilitating installation are treated as GFP, and permanently removed items are dispositioned per Government direction. Nonconforming products are managed by Field's Material Review Board (MRB) following established procedures, with customer approval obtained for use-as-is or repair dispositions. Disposal of obsolete, non-repairable, or non-reusable parts is conducted using specific instructions provided by the Government or prime contractor, ensuring positive accountability and traceability. Field Aerospace maintains compliance with AS9100D and ISO 10012 quality standards, hazardous materials management programs, and environmental regulations to safely handle and dispose of hazardous waste. This process ensures accountability, regulatory compliance, and environmental stewardship throughout equipment removal and disposal activities.","type":"Technical Written Response"}]

[{"question":"Describe the programmatic support structure, including identification and responsibilities of the Program Manager for the modification program.","section":"Program Management","response":"Field Aerospace has a structured programmatic support framework for modification programs, appointing a dedicated Program Manager to ensure adherence to the Statement of Work (SOW) and timely achievement of deliverables. The Program Manager oversees all program aspects, coordinating closely with a Focal Engineer responsible for engineering matters. The management team may also include procurement, quality, and planning specialists, along with production coordinators as needed. Field Aerospace applies established program management practices tailored to project-specific requirements, enabling proactive control over progress, cost, schedule, and quality. Regular program status reports and teleconferences facilitate effective communication and issue resolution with the customer, ensuring comprehensive oversight and successful program execution through experienced leadership and a robust internal management system.","type":"Technical Written Response"}]

[{"question":"Describe the planning and implementation of oversight for engineering design, development, and installation activities, and the process for developing and maintaining an Integrated Master Schedule (IMS).","section":"Program Planning and Control","response":"Field Aerospace has a robust process for planning and implementing oversight of engineering design, development, and installation activities. This process includes adherence to AS9100D and ISO 10012 quality standards, ensuring rigorous quality assurance and control throughout all phases. Field Aerospace employs a structured Quality Management System (QMS) that integrates process control, in-process inspections, and statistical quality control to minimize risk and maintain high-quality outputs. Oversight is maintained by qualified engineering and quality personnel who monitor compliance with design requirements, regulatory standards, and customer specifications. For schedule management, Field Aerospace develops and maintains an Integrated Master Schedule (IMS) that is a detailed, networked, time-based schedule encompassing all tasks necessary for successful program execution. The IMS is derived from the Integrated Master Plan (IMP) and includes milestones, deliverables, and risk mitigation activities. This schedule is continuously updated and reviewed to ensure alignment with project goals and timely delivery. Field Aerospace's past performance on complex avionics and mission system modifications demonstrates its capability to effectively manage engineering oversight and schedule control to meet customer requirements.","type":"Technical Written Response"}]

[{"question":"Describe the management of subcontractors to ensure schedule, cost, quality, and performance requirements are met.","section":"Subcontractor Management","response":"Field Aerospace uses a comprehensive subcontractor management approach to ensure schedule, cost, quality, and performance requirements are consistently met. This includes rigorous subcontractor selection based on qualifications and past performance, detailed flow-down of contract requirements, and integration of subcontractor activities into the overall program schedule and budget. Field Aerospace employs AS9100D-compliant quality management systems to monitor subcontractor quality through regular audits, inspections, and performance reviews. Earned Value Management (EVM) techniques are applied to track cost and schedule adherence. Communication is maintained through regular status meetings and reporting, enabling early identification and mitigation of risks. Additionally, Field Aerospace enforces strict configuration control and documentation protocols to ensure subcontractor deliverables meet technical and contractual standards, thereby supporting successful program execution and customer satisfaction.","type":"Technical Written Response"}]

Field Aerospace has a structured process for hosting post-award conferences to ensure clear communication and alignment on contract requirements. The agenda typically includes introductions, contract scope review, schedule and milestone discussions, quality assurance protocols, risk management, and roles and responsibilities. Contract requirements are thoroughly addressed, emphasizing compliance with applicable standards such as AS9100D and ISO 10012. During the conference, Field Aerospace ensures all technical, quality, and programmatic aspects are discussed to mitigate risks and clarify expectations. Conference minutes are meticulously documented, capturing key discussions, decisions, and assigned action items with responsible parties and due dates. These minutes are promptly distributed to all stakeholders to maintain transparency and accountability. This disciplined approach supports effective contract execution and fosters collaborative relationships with customers.

[{"question":"Describe the process for hosting an aircraft induction readiness review, including delivery of review minutes and action items.","section":"Induction Readiness Review","response":"Field Aerospace will conduct an aircraft induction readiness review through a structured process aligned with AS9100D and ISO 9001:2015 standards. The process begins with a comprehensive pre-induction inspection to assess the aircraft's condition and readiness for modification or maintenance activities, including verification of configuration control, equipment inventory, and review of technical data and maintenance records. A multidisciplinary team of quality inspectors, engineers, and program managers participates in the review, covering compliance with technical requirements, safety standards, and project milestones. Discrepancies or issues identified are documented as action items. Following the review, Field Aerospace prepares and delivers formal review minutes summarizing findings, decisions, and assigned action items. These minutes are distributed to stakeholders to ensure clear communication and accountability. Action items are tracked through the project management system until closure, ensuring timely resolution and readiness for aircraft induction. This process is supported by Field Aerospace's robust Quality Management System emphasizing continuous improvement and documentation.","type":"Technical Written Response"}]

{"question":"Describe the process for providing monthly program status reports, including highlights of progress, key milestones, and risks or issues.","section":"Progress Status Report","response":"Field Aerospace has a structured process for providing monthly program status reports that ensures comprehensive communication of project progress, key milestones, and risk management. Our program management office compiles detailed reports that highlight accomplishments against the project schedule, including completed tasks and upcoming milestones. We utilize quality management standards such as AS9100D and ISO 10012 to maintain rigorous documentation and data accuracy. Risks and issues are identified, assessed, and tracked with mitigation plans clearly outlined. The reports include status updates on government-furnished equipment accountability, configuration control, and any deviations or nonconformances. These reports are reviewed by the program manager and distributed to stakeholders to facilitate informed decision-making and proactive resolution of potential impacts to schedule or performance.","type":"Technical Written Response"}

[{"question":"Describe the quality system to be provided and maintained, including adherence to AS9100D and requirements for sub-tier suppliers.","section":"Quality","response":"Field Aerospace has a robust quality system that complies fully with AS9100D standards, ensuring rigorous quality management tailored for the aerospace industry. Our quality system encompasses comprehensive process controls, documentation, and continuous improvement practices to maintain high standards throughout all phases of design, manufacture, installation, and certification. We extend these quality requirements to our sub-tier suppliers by mandating their compliance with AS9100D or equivalent recognized aerospace quality standards. This includes supplier qualification, regular audits, and performance monitoring to ensure adherence to quality expectations and contractual obligations. Our quality assurance team oversees supplier management, ensuring that all critical processes and source requirements flow down to sub-tier suppliers, maintaining traceability and accountability. This integrated approach guarantees that all components and services meet stringent aerospace quality and safety requirements, supporting mission success and customer satisfaction.","type":"Technical Written Response"}]

[{"question":"Provide evidence of certification as a Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) approved Repair Station for performing aircraft maintenance and modifications.","section":"Quality","response":"Field Aerospace has FAA Part 145 Repair Station certification, demonstrating its approval by the Federal Aviation Administration to perform aircraft maintenance and modifications. The company maintains compliance with FAA regulations under 14 CFR Part 145, ensuring all maintenance, preventive maintenance, and alterations are conducted to the highest standards for airworthiness. Field Aerospace's repair station operates under strict quality management systems aligned with aerospace industry standards such as AS9100D and ISO 10012. The company has extensive experience with over 300 Supplemental Type Certificates and supports a broad range of aircraft platforms, underscoring its capability to perform certified maintenance and modifications. Documentation protocols include maintaining detailed maintenance records, issuing authorized release certificates (FAA Form 8130-3), and ensuring traceability and compliance with FAA and customer requirements. Field Aerospace's facilities, processes, and personnel qualifications collectively ensure adherence to FAA-approved repair station standards for aircraft maintenance and modifications.","type":"Technical Written Response"}]

[{"question":"Describe the approach to physical security for the modification aircraft and all FAC provided equipment, tools, and materials at the Contractor’s facility.","section":"Security","response":"Field Aerospace has established a comprehensive physical security approach at its contractor facility to safeguard modification aircraft and all contractor-provided equipment, tools, and materials. The company operates under a Quality Management System certified to AS9100D and ISO 9001 standards, which includes stringent property management controls compliant with FAR 52.245-1. This ensures effective control, protection, storage, and maintenance of all assets. Access to the facility is strictly controlled, and Foreign Object Debris (FOD) prevention and tool control programs are enforced to maintain a secure work environment. Additionally, all personnel undergo mandatory security and threat awareness training in accordance with applicable regulations. These integrated measures collectively ensure the integrity and security of all aircraft and equipment throughout the modification process.","type":"Technical Written Response"}]

[{"question":"Describe the process for submitting over-and-above (O&A) requests, including required details and approval process.","section":"Over-and-Above","response":"Field Aerospace has a structured process for submitting Over-and-Above (O&A) requests to ensure clarity, compliance, and timely approval. When the need for O&A work is identified during contract performance, Field Aerospace prepares a detailed work request that includes the scope of the additional work, technical justification, estimated cost, and schedule impact. This request is submitted to the Government in accordance with the agreed contract procedures. The Government then promptly reviews the request for approval. Field Aerospace maintains rigorous documentation and traceability of all O&A requests and approvals, ensuring alignment with contract terms and quality standards such as AS9100D and ISO 10012. The process includes negotiation and definitization of pricing for the O&A work, with contract modifications executed to formalize the changes. This approach ensures that all additional work is properly authorized, documented, and integrated into the project schedule and budget.","type":"Technical Written Response"}]

[{"question":"Describe the warranty provided for workmanship on installation services, including duration and terms.","section":"Warranty","response":"Field Aerospace has a comprehensive warranty policy for workmanship on installation services. We provide a warranty that covers defects in workmanship for a defined duration, typically one year, ensuring that all installation work meets the highest quality standards. Our warranty terms include prompt correction of any workmanship deficiencies identified during the warranty period at no additional cost to the customer. Field Aerospace adheres to rigorous quality assurance standards including AS9100D and ISO 10012, and maintains thorough documentation and inspection protocols to support warranty claims. Our experienced technicians and engineers perform installations with meticulous attention to detail, backed by a robust quality management system. This warranty reflects our commitment to customer satisfaction and confidence in the durability and reliability of our installation services.","type":"Technical Written Response"}]

json.pmQuestions: [{"question":"The design, development, and installations shall be in accordance with the agreed delivery schedule at the time of the contract award and any subsequent contract amendments. The Contractor shall ensure aircraft are inducted nose-to-tail with a seven-calendar day overlap unless otherwise specified in the approved schedule.","section":"Schedule","response":"Field Aerospace will rigorously adhere to the agreed delivery schedule established at contract award and any subsequent amendments, ensuring all design, development, and installation activities are executed on time and within scope. Our project management approach incorporates detailed schedule planning and control mechanisms, leveraging proven aerospace industry standards and internal best practices to maintain schedule integrity. We employ a structured aircraft induction process that sequences aircraft nose-to-tail with a mandatory seven-calendar day overlap, facilitating efficient resource allocation, minimizing downtime, and ensuring continuity of work. This overlap period is closely monitored and adjusted only when approved in the formal schedule to accommodate any operational or technical constraints. Risk management practices are integrated into schedule oversight to identify, assess, and mitigate potential delays proactively. Regular communication with all stakeholders, including the customer and subcontractors, ensures transparency and timely resolution of schedule-related issues. Field Aerospace’s commitment to disciplined schedule management and collaborative coordination guarantees delivery milestones are met, supporting mission success and customer satisfaction.","type":"Scheduling/Deliverables"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall provide data revisions to the aircraft flight, inspection, wiring, and maintenance manuals, as required, to reflect the aircraft modifications. (CDRL A001)","section":"Revision of Technical Data","response":"Field Aerospace will provide timely and accurate revisions to all required aircraft flight, inspection, wiring, and maintenance manuals to reflect the aircraft modifications. Our approach is supported by a comprehensive quality management system (QMS) compliant with AS9100D standards, ensuring all technical data updates meet or exceed customer and regulatory requirements. We employ a controlled configuration management system to maintain engineering design data and revision history, with qualified personnel responsible for managing and maintaining these records. Revisions are documented, controlled, and delivered in accordance with contract data requirements. Integration of these data revisions into our project management plan (PMP) ensures adherence to schedule, quality, and compliance milestones. Additionally, robust communication and status reporting mechanisms keep stakeholders informed throughout the project lifecycle. Field Aerospace also conducts audits and surveillance to verify compliance by internal teams and subcontractors with technical data revision requirements, ensuring the highest standards of accuracy and reliability in all documentation.","type":"Administrative Coordination/Recordkeeping"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall record all accomplished modification efforts and deficiencies found in the aircraft records. Any discrepancies found will be coordinated for approved/disapproved for work through the FAC representative. Contractor’s work documents shall be utilized during the modification. Upon completion of the modification, the work records will be transcribed to the FAC aircraft record documents. (CDRL A002)","section":"Aircraft Records","response":"Field Aerospace has developed a comprehensive administrative coordination and recordkeeping process to ensure full compliance with the requirement to document all modification efforts and deficiencies in aircraft records. Our approach includes rigorous tracking of all accomplished modifications and identification of any discrepancies during the work. All discrepancies are formally coordinated with the FAC representative for approval or disapproval, ensuring clear communication and resolution. We utilize contractor work documents as the primary source during modification activities, maintaining detailed and controlled records throughout the process. Upon completion, all work records are accurately transcribed into the FAC aircraft record documents (CDRL A002), preserving traceability and contractual compliance. Our quality assurance and control teams oversee this process, conducting regular audits and reviews to maintain data integrity and ensure that all deficiencies are addressed and documented appropriately. This structured methodology aligns with industry standards and Field Aerospace’s internal quality management system, providing confidence in the accuracy and completeness of aircraft records throughout the modification lifecycle.","type":"Administrative Coordination/Recordkeeping"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall provide FAC with a list of all logbook entries being carried forward to FAC home station prior to aircraft acceptance. (CDRL A003)","section":"Aircraft Records","response":"Field Aerospace has developed and implemented robust procedures for managing aircraft logbook entries in compliance with regulatory and contractual requirements. Prior to aircraft acceptance, Field Aerospace will compile a comprehensive list of all logbook entries that document maintenance, inspections, modifications, and other relevant activities performed on the aircraft. This list will be provided to FAC to ensure full traceability and continuity of the aircraft's maintenance and operational history. Our process guarantees that all logbook entries carried forward to the FAC home station are accurate, complete, and properly documented, supporting FAC's oversight and airworthiness verification. This approach aligns with industry best practices and facilitates a seamless transition of the aircraft with full documentation integrity, meeting the requirements of CDRL A003.","type":"Administrative Coordination/Recordkeeping"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall perform an incoming overall condition inspection with a FAC representative for incoming aircraft utilizing the Contractor’s internal processes to document incoming aircraft status and condition. The Contractor shall provide documented results of the inspection to FAC representative within 7 calendar days following the inspection. (CDRL A004)","section":"Inspections","response":"Field Aerospace will perform the incoming overall condition inspection of aircraft in strict accordance with its established internal quality management system (QMS) and government property management procedures. The inspection will be conducted jointly with a FAC representative to ensure transparency and mutual agreement on the aircraft's status and condition upon receipt. Our process includes a detailed visual and functional assessment aligned with aerospace industry standards and regulatory requirements to verify airworthiness and compliance.

Inspection results will be thoroughly documented using standardized forms and records management systems, capturing all relevant data such as part numbers, serial numbers, condition notes, and any discrepancies or damage observed. This documentation will be reviewed and approved by qualified quality control personnel before submission.

Field Aerospace commits to delivering the documented inspection results to the FAC representative within 7 calendar days following the inspection, meeting the contractual requirement (CDRL A004). Our project management approach ensures timely communication, accountability, and adherence to quality standards throughout the inspection and reporting process, thereby supporting the overall mission modernization objectives with minimal risk and maximum reliability.","type":"Quality Control/Administrative Coordination"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall facilitate acceptance inspections with the FAC representative after successful aircraft post-installation checkout and acceptance check flight.","section":"Inspections","response":"Field Aerospace will ensure thorough facilitation of acceptance inspections with the FAC representative following successful aircraft post-installation checkout and acceptance check flight. Our approach includes detailed coordination and scheduling of inspections to align with the FAC representative's availability and program milestones. We employ a structured quality control process that verifies all avionics and mission modernization installations meet contractual and regulatory requirements prior to acceptance. This includes comprehensive documentation of inspection results, identification and resolution of any discrepancies, and formal sign-off procedures to confirm acceptance criteria are met.

Our quality assurance team works closely with engineering and manufacturing to support the post-installation checkout, ensuring all systems are fully operational and compliant with technical specifications. The acceptance check flight is conducted under controlled conditions with qualified personnel to validate system performance and integration. Field Aerospace maintains clear communication channels with all stakeholders to provide timely updates and address any issues promptly.

This disciplined approach minimizes risk, supports schedule adherence, and ensures the delivery of a fully functional and compliant aircraft modernization. Field Aerospace's commitment to quality and customer satisfaction is demonstrated through our rigorous acceptance inspection facilitation process, which aligns with aerospace industry standards and best practices.","type":"Quality Control/Administrative Coordination"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall provide programmatic support for the modification program.","section":"Program Management","response":"Field Aerospace will provide comprehensive programmatic support tailored to the modification program requirements. Our approach includes establishing a dedicated Program Management Office (PMO) staffed with experienced, PMI-certified professionals who utilize proven project management methodologies to ensure effective planning, execution, and control of all program activities. We will develop and maintain a detailed Project Management Plan (PMP) that outlines technical, schedule, and cost objectives, resource allocation, risk management strategies, and subcontractor oversight. The PMP will be reviewed and updated regularly to reflect program status and changes.

Field Aerospace employs integrated program teams (IPTs) to facilitate cross-functional collaboration and communication among engineering, production, quality, procurement, and other key stakeholders. We use industry-standard tools such as Microsoft Project for scheduling and JDE for cost and material tracking, supported by robust reporting mechanisms to monitor progress, identify risks, and implement corrective actions promptly.

Our programmatic support also includes regular status reporting, risk assessments, and management reviews to ensure transparency and alignment with customer expectations. We emphasize proactive risk management by maintaining a risk register, conducting weekly reviews, and escalating issues as needed. Additionally, we ensure compliance with all contractual and regulatory requirements, including government property management and quality assurance standards.

Through these structured program management practices, Field Aerospace will deliver reliable, efficient, and compliant programmatic support to successfully execute the modification program.","type":"Project Management Plan"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall identify and maintain a single POC (Program Manager) for all tasks required for the modification program. The Program Manager shall be responsible and shall have authority for the control and coordination of all work performed under the contract.","section":"Program Management","response":"Field Aerospace will designate a single Program Manager (PM) as the sole point of contact for all aspects of the modification program. This PM will have full responsibility and authority to control and coordinate all contract activities, ensuring seamless integration of technical, schedule, and cost elements. The PM will serve as the primary interface with the customer and internal stakeholders, facilitating clear and timely communication to promote transparency and rapid issue resolution. Our PMs are experienced professionals empowered to make decisions within the scope of the contract, approve purchases and services supporting the program, and manage resources effectively to meet program objectives. Field Aerospace’s established Program Management Office (PMO) employs standardized procedures and tools, including a tailored Program Management Plan (PMP), to provide structured oversight and control. The PMP defines roles, responsibilities, communication protocols, and risk management strategies to ensure accountability and program success. Regular status reporting, milestone tracking, and risk mitigation activities will be conducted under the PM’s leadership to maintain schedule adherence and quality standards. This approach aligns with industry best practices and Field Aerospace’s commitment to delivering high-quality, on-time, and within-budget solutions. The PM’s authority and accountability are critical to achieving the program’s goals and maintaining customer satisfaction throughout the contract lifecycle.","type":"Staffing/Roles/Communication Protocols"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall be responsible for planning and implementing oversight for the engineering design, development, and installation activities. The Contractor shall develop, maintain, and provide an Integrated Master Schedule (IMS) to the FAC representative. The IMS shall be updated monthly until completion of the aircraft installations. (CDRL A005)","section":"Program Planning and Control","response":"Field Aerospace will assume full responsibility for planning and implementing oversight of the engineering design, development, and installation activities as required. We have developed a robust Project Management Plan (PMP) that incorporates a comprehensive Integrated Master Schedule (IMS). This IMS is a detailed, time-based, networked schedule that encompasses all tasks necessary to ensure successful program execution. It is maintained and updated monthly to provide clear visibility into project progress, resource allocation, and milestone achievement. Our IMS is fully integrated with the overall program management approach, aligning with technical, quality, and procurement plans to ensure cohesive execution. Field Aerospace will provide the IMS as a formal deliverable to the FAC representative and will update it regularly to reflect current status and forecast upcoming activities. This approach facilitates proactive management, effective oversight, and clear communication with all stakeholders, ensuring timely delivery and compliance with contract requirements throughout the aircraft installation process.","type":"Project Management Plan/Scheduling/Deliverables"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall host an aircraft induction readiness review within 30 calendar days prior to start of first aircraft modification. Review minutes including action items shall be delivered 15 calendar days after the review. (CDRL A007)","section":"Induction Readiness Review","response":"Field Aerospace will assign a dedicated Program Manager (PM) to coordinate and lead the aircraft induction readiness review, ensuring it is conducted within 30 calendar days prior to the start of the first aircraft modification. The PM will engage all relevant stakeholders to assess readiness factors including resources, tooling, personnel, and technical data. Utilizing a structured Project Management Plan (PMP) that integrates schedule, risk management, and quality assurance, Field Aerospace will ensure thorough preparation and execution of the review. Comprehensive minutes documenting all action items, responsible parties, and due dates will be prepared and delivered within 15 calendar days after the review as CDRL A007. This process guarantees clear communication, accountability, and timely resolution of any issues, thereby minimizing risk and supporting successful program execution.","type":"Administrative Coordination/Project Management Plan"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall provide monthly program status reports for the duration of the contract. The report shall be in Contractor’s format and as a minimum include highlights of progress against key milestones and risks or issues affecting the program. (CDRL A008)","section":"Progress Status Report","response":"Field Aerospace will provide comprehensive monthly program status reports throughout the contract duration. These reports will be prepared in Field Aerospace’s proprietary format, tailored to clearly communicate key program information to stakeholders. Each report will include a summary of progress against established key milestones, highlighting completed tasks, upcoming activities, and any deviations from the planned schedule. Additionally, the reports will identify and assess risks or issues impacting the program, including mitigation actions and escalation status. This structured reporting approach ensures transparency, facilitates proactive risk management, and supports informed decision-making by program leadership and the customer. Field Aerospace’s program manager will review and validate the reports prior to submission, ensuring accuracy and relevance. Regular status reporting is integrated into Field Aerospace’s project management system, enabling timely data collection and consistent communication. This commitment to thorough and clear monthly reporting aligns with contract requirements and promotes effective program oversight and coordination.","type":"Project Management Plan/Risk Management/Administrative Coordination"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall provide and maintain a quality system that as a minimum adheres to the requirements of AS9100D for Quality Assurance in design, development, production, installation and servicing. The Contractor shall require of sub‐tier suppliers a quality system achieving control of the quality of the services and supplies provided.","section":"Quality","response":"Field Aerospace will implement and maintain a comprehensive quality management system (QMS) that fully complies with the requirements of AS9100D, the aerospace industry standard for quality assurance in design, development, production, installation, and servicing. Our QMS is certified to AS9100D and integrates all necessary processes to ensure product and service quality, regulatory compliance, and continuous improvement. We have established documented procedures and controls that govern all phases of the project lifecycle, including rigorous inspection, testing, and verification activities. Our quality assurance program plan (QAPP) is tailored to the specific requirements of the FAC SR-560 Tracker Avionics and Mission Modernization Statement of Work (SOW), ensuring that all contract deliverables meet or exceed customer expectations. Field Aerospace requires all sub-tier suppliers to implement quality systems that achieve effective control over the quality of the services and supplies they provide. We flow down applicable quality requirements and contract clauses to subcontractors and monitor their performance through audits, assessments, and regular communication. Sub-tier suppliers must demonstrate compliance with AS9100D or equivalent quality standards, and provide evidence of their quality system effectiveness. Our Government Property Management Plan and Supplier Control processes ensure proper handling, accountability, and control of government-furnished property and materials throughout the supply chain. We maintain detailed records, conduct physical inventories, and enforce corrective actions as needed to mitigate risks. Through these integrated quality control processes, Field Aerospace assures the delivery of high-quality, reliable avionics and mission modernization solutions while maintaining compliance with all contractual and regulatory quality requirements.","type":"Quality Control Processes"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall hold and maintain certification as a Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) approved Repair Station for performing aircraft maintenance and modifications.","section":"Quality","response":"Field Aerospace maintains certification as a Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) approved Repair Station, fully compliant with 14 CFR Part 145 requirements. Our quality control system is rigorously established and maintained to ensure the airworthiness of all aircraft maintenance, preventive maintenance, and alterations performed. This system aligns with FAA standards and includes comprehensive documentation such as a Repair Station Manual and Quality Control Manual, developed in accordance with FAA Advisory Circular 145-9 guidance. Field Aerospace's quality assurance processes encompass detailed inspections, traceability of parts, control of nonconforming products, and final inspections to verify compliance with all contract and regulatory requirements. Our repair station certification enables us to perform aircraft maintenance and modifications with the highest standards of safety, reliability, and regulatory compliance, ensuring that all work meets or exceeds FAA airworthiness standards.","type":"Quality Control Processes/Administrative Coordination"}]

[{"question":"The Contractor shall submit over-and-above (O&A) requests for repair and replacement items outside the scope of this SOW. O&A requests shall be submitted per event and shall include specific effort, skills required, and hours required per skill. Each O&A work request must be approved in writing by the FAC representative before work is started.","section":"Over-and-Above","response":"Field Aerospace has established a rigorous process for managing Over-and-Above (O&A) requests to ensure compliance with contract requirements and effective change management. For any repair or replacement items outside the scope of the Statement of Work (SOW), Field Aerospace will submit O&A requests on a per-event basis. Each request will detail the specific effort involved, the skills required, and the estimated hours per skill category necessary to complete the work. This detailed breakdown facilitates transparent evaluation and approval by the FAC representative. No O&A work will commence without prior written approval from the FAC representative, ensuring strict adherence to contract terms and preventing unauthorized work. Field Aerospace’s approach aligns with industry standards and federal acquisition regulations governing O&A work, emphasizing clear documentation, formal approval processes, and accountability. This process supports effective administrative coordination, change management, and recordkeeping, thereby minimizing risk and maintaining program integrity throughout contract performance.","type":"Administrative Coordination/Change Management/Recordkeeping","section":"Over-and-Above"}]

introduction.Overview: Field Aerospace, established in 1947, is a distinguished U.S.-owned aerospace company headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio, with primary aircraft modification and maintenance facilities located in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. With over 75 years of experience, Field Aerospace has earned a reputation as a center of excellence in aircraft engineering, integration, and modifications, serving commercial, military, and special mission customers worldwide. The company specializes in making ordinary aircraft extraordinary by providing comprehensive solutions that encompass design, manufacture, installation, testing, certification, and ongoing support of aircraft modifications and upgrades.
introduction.Facilities: Field Aerospace operates a state-of-the-art 160,000 square foot dual-hangar facility at Will Rogers World Airport in Oklahoma City, complemented by 426,225 square feet of ramp space capable of accommodating multiple aircraft types simultaneously. The facility is certified as a 14 CFR Part 145 Repair Station, holds FAA Organization Designation Authorization (ODA), and is AS9100D certified, ensuring compliance with the highest quality and safety standards. Equipped with advanced manufacturing, fabrication, and testing capabilities, the facility supports flight-line, intermediate, and depot-level maintenance, as well as complex aircraft modifications and upgrades. The presence of Defense Contract Management Agency (DCMA) representatives on-site further underscores the facility’s commitment to government contract compliance and quality assurance.
introduction.Capabilities: Field Aerospace offers a comprehensive suite of capabilities including design engineering, systems integration, prototyping, ground and flight testing, and certification. The company excels in structural and aerodynamic modifications, avionics and mission system installations, and special mission aircraft solutions. With over 300 Supplemental Type Certificates (STCs) across turboprop, jet, and rotorcraft platforms, Field Aerospace has direct experience with more than 23 aircraft types, including Gulfstream GII, G-IV, G550, Bombardier Challenger, CRJ series, C-130, KC-10, and various rotorcraft. The company’s engineering team employs advanced CAD and finite element analysis tools to ensure design validation and compliance. Additionally, Field Aerospace provides extensive customer support services such as technical publications, logistics, training, and 24/7 AOG support.
introduction.Certifications and Quality: Field Aerospace maintains rigorous quality management systems certified to ISO 9001 and AS9100D standards. The company is an FAA-certified Part 145 Repair Station and holds an FAA Organization Designation Authorization (ODA), enabling in-house certification and delegation authority for aircraft modifications. This capability significantly reduces program risk and accelerates certification timelines. Field Aerospace also complies with ITAR and export control regulations, maintaining registrations with the Directorate of Defense Trade Controls (DDTC) and the Canadian Controlled Goods Program (CGP), ensuring secure handling of sensitive technologies and data.
introduction.Core Competencies: Field Aerospace’s core competencies encompass the full lifecycle of aircraft modification programs, from initial concept and design through production, installation, testing, certification, and sustainment. The company’s expertise includes avionics upgrades, special mission system integration, structural modifications, and comprehensive program management. Their multidisciplinary engineering team supports complex system integrations and multi-platform modifications, backed by experienced production supervisors, certified mechanics, avionics technicians, and quality inspectors. Field Aerospace’s program management office employs PMI-certified professionals who utilize integrated program teams to deliver projects on time and within budget, ensuring customer satisfaction and mission success.
introduction.Relevant Experience: Field Aerospace has a proven track record of successful aircraft modification programs for government and commercial customers, including recent projects such as the installation of CNS/ATM systems on 59 KC-10 aircraft and multiple modifications on Gulfstream IV-SP and G550 platforms for special mission roles. The company has supported MIT Lincoln Laboratory on several testbed platforms, demonstrating its capability to meet complex and unique modification requirements. Field Aerospace’s extensive experience with FAA, Transport Canada, and EASA certifications, combined with its robust engineering and manufacturing resources, positions it as a low-risk, highly capable partner for advanced aircraft modification programs.

json.documentText:
Fuerza Aèrea Colombiana (FAC)
Colombian Air Force
SR-560 Tracker Avionics and Mission Modernization
Statement of Work (SOW)






Date: 02/12/2024

Table of Contents

DESCRIPTION OF SERVICES
Purpose
This Statement of Work (SOW) defines the Contractor’s requirements for accomplishing the design, development, and installation of a modernized avionics suite and enhanced mission systems on Fuerza Aèrea Colombiana (FAC) SR-560 Tracker aircraft. The aircraft modification provides the FAC with an avionics upgrade and mission systems improvements that avoid overall shortcomings in reliability, maintainability, and supportability of the current equipment.
Program Objectives

Program Objectives
Five FAC SR-560 (Cessna OT-47B Citation Ultra 560) aircraft shall be modified to incorporate upgraded cockpit avionics, mission computers, mission displays, mission consoles/workstations, mission software, cabin interphones, and video recorders. The modifications shall utilize commercially available off-the shelf equipment and be installed in accordance with the Contractor’s FAC approved design. The Contractor shall provide the Group A-Kits, Group B-Kits, and software necessary to accomplish the modifications.
Reference Documents
The documents shown below should be used as guidance.
U.S. Military Standards
Commerical Standards
Schedule

Reference Documents
The documents shown below should be used as guidance.
U.S. Military Standards
Commerical Standards
Schedule
The design, development, and installations shall be in accordance with the agreed delivery schedule at the time of the contract award and any subsequent contract amendments. The Contractor shall ensure aircraft are inducted nose-to-tail with a seven-calendar day overlap unless otherwise specified in the approved schedule.
REQUIREMENTS
Engineering Design and Development
The Contractor shall design and develop an installation drawing package to integrate the modification equipment into the aircraft that complies with applicable airworthiness requirements as specified in MIL-HDBK-516C.

The modification equipment shall not limit current aircraft and mission performance capabilities and shall be fully compatible with the existing AN/APG-66 radar and forward looking infra-red (FLIR) surveillance camera.
The modification equipment configuration shall not adversely affect the center of gravity (CG) of the aircraft.
The modification equipment shall not inhibit any component’s ability to function continuously throughout the full environmental and operational range of the aircraft per the approved flight manual.
Cockpit Avionics
The Contractor shall replace the current pilots’ displays with high resolution picture displays that are brighter, clearer, and run cooler than the current displays.

The Contractor shall enhance flight safety through the integration of the following performance features:
Provides updated cockpit displays from cathode ray tubes (CRT) with liquid crystal displays (LCD). 
Airport charts for visual awareness on the runway and taxiways.
Approach charts for graphical depiction of aircraft position during approach.
Integrated map for 2D depiction of flight plan, weather, traffic and geographical boundaries.
Mission Computer
The Contractor shall replace the current mission computer with an ultra-small form factor rugged computer capable of low-power (typically < 25W) operation with 28 VDC input power.
The Contractor shall ensure the mission computer meets the following minimum capabilities:
MIL-performance circular connectors.

The Contractor shall ensure the mission computer meets the following minimum capabilities:
MIL-performance circular connectors.
Minimum of two 1000BaseT Ethernet ports with low-latency Time Sensitive Networking (TSN) support for real-time networking.
Minimum of three slots for PCIe mini-cards for add-on I/O (e.g., MIL-STD-1553 and ARINC429).
Minimum of 16GB DDR memory.
Minimum of 64GB on-board solid-state data storage.
MIL-STD-810 or DO-160 thermal, shock, vibration, altitude, and humidity qualified.
MIL-STD-461 or DO-160 EMI/EMC qualified.
Mission Display
The Contractor shall replace the current mission monitors with full-color, sunlight-readable, multi-functional display (MFD) that fits into the existing positions in the cockpit.

The Contractor shall ensure the mission displays meet the following functional capabilities:
Provides updated cockpit displays from cathode ray tubes (CRT) with liquid crystal displays (LCD). 
Integrates with Honeywell Primus avionics suite.
Airport charts for visual awareness on the runway and taxiways.
Approach charts for graphical depiction of aircraft position during approach.
Integrated map for 2D depiction of flight plan, weather, traffic and geographical boundaries.
Provides inputs from mission system video from radar and EO/IR turret.
Display controls for switching display information from video sources.
Mission Console / Workstation

Display controls for switching display information from video sources.
Mission Console / Workstation
The Contractor shall replace the current mission console monitors with full-color, sunlight-readable, displays that fit into the existing monitor positions in each mission workstation. 
The Contractor shall ensure the mission console monitors meet the following minimum capabilities:
MIL-performance circular connectors.
16:9 aspect ratio and 1000:1 contrast ratio with a minimum of 1920 x 1080 pixels resolution.
28 VDC input power and typically <90W power draw.
Composite video, DisplayPort, HDMI, and VGA inputs.
On-screen display controls.
Dimmable with anti-reflective coating.
MIL-STD-810 or DO-160 thermal, shock, vibration, altitude, and humidity qualified.
MIL-STD-461 EMI/EMC qualified.

MIL-STD-810 or DO-160 thermal, shock, vibration, altitude, and humidity qualified.
MIL-STD-461 EMI/EMC qualified.
The Contractor shall replace the current mission keyboard with a ruggedized 1U keyboard with an integrated track ball or touch pad that is qualified to MIL-STD-810 or DO-160 for thermal, shock, vibration, altitude, and humidity.
The contractor shall replace the current control grip with an ergonomic cobra-style control grip with           6 programmable function capabilities including 4-way momentary action switch, 2-position pushbutton momentary action switches, and trigger switch. The control grip shall meet MIL-STD-810 or DO-160 minimum environmental specifications.
Mission Software

Mission Software
The Contractor shall upgrade current integrated sensor control and image analysis software with advanced capabilities including:
Providing mission functionality between APG-66 radar and EO/IR turret. 
Mission playback, storage, and export with forensic archival and retrieval.
Cabin Interphone
The Contractor shall upgrade the current cabin internal communication system (ICS) with a dual-net ICS capable of isolating mission cabin communications from cockpit with selectable integration with all intercom stations. The ICS shall interface with all legacy radios (e.g., HF, UHF, VHF, SATCOM).
Video Recorder

Video Recorder
The Contractor shall replace current Digital Video Recorders (DVR) with advanced solid-state DVRs capable of audio and color video recording and integration of radar and other sensor inputs. The DVR shall have removable storage for data retrieval and analysis. The Contractor shall ensure the DVR system meets the following minimum capabilities:
Lighter weight compared to current equipment.
Support for 1080p resolution.
28 VDC power input.
FLIR System
The Contractor shall upgrade the current forward looking infra-red (FLIR) system to the 380 HDX configuration with advanced image aiding, improved targeting and performance capabilities.
Revision of Technical Data

Revision of Technical Data
The Contractor shall provide data revisions to the aircraft flight, inspection, wiring, and maintenance manuals, as required, to reflect the aircraft modifications. (CDRL A001)
Aircraft Modification
The Contractor shall modify each aircraft installing the Group A-Kit, Group B-Kit, and software in accordance with the approved installation drawing package and applicable aircraft manuals.
The Contractor shall provide ramp space and/or hangar for the modification aircraft. In the event of severe weather, which pose as a risk to the aircraft, the Contractor shall protect the aircraft to the maximum extent possible.
Aircraft Records

Aircraft Records
The Contractor shall record all accomplished modification efforts and deficiencies found in the aircraft records. Any discrepancies found will be coordinated for approved/disapproved for work through the FAC representative. Contractor’s work documents shall be utilized during the modification. Upon completion of the modification, the work records will be transcribed to the FAC aircraft record documents. (CDRL A002)
The Contractor shall provide FAC with a list of all logbook entries being carried forward to FAC home station prior to aircraft acceptance. (CDRL A003)
Inspections

Inspections
The Contractor shall perform an incoming overall condition inspection with a FAC representative for incoming aircraft utilizing the Contractor’s internal processes to document incoming aircraft status and condition. The Contractor shall provide documented results of the inspection to FAC representative within 7 calendar days following the inspection. (CDRL A004)
The Contractor shall facilitate acceptance inspections with the FAC representative after successful aircraft post-installation checkout and acceptance check flight.
Acceptance Check Flight
The Contractor shall support the FAC aircrew conducting acceptance check flights. The Contractor shall provide required maintenance crew to support the acceptance check flights and other related flight operations.
Equipment Disposal

Equipment Disposal
The Contractor shall return to FAC all equipment items removed from the aircraft and not reinstalled with a tagged status condition of “As Is” or “Unknown”. Other removed materials (e.g., wiring, connectors, brackets) shall be condemned in place and discarded as scrap.
Program Management
The Contractor shall provide programmatic support for the modification program.
The Contractor shall identify and maintain a single POC (Program Manager) for all tasks required for the modification program. The Program Manager shall be responsible and shall have authority for the control and coordination of all work performed under the contract.
Program Planning and Control

Program Planning and Control
The Contractor shall be responsible for planning and implementing oversight for the engineering design, development, and installation activities. The Contractor shall develop, maintain, and provide an Integrated Master Schedule (IMS) to the FAC representative. The IMS shall be updated monthly until completion of the aircraft installations. (CDRL A005)
Subcontractor Management
The Contractor shall manage their subcontractors in such a manner that schedule, cost, quality and performance problems are identified and resolved in a manner which avoids impact to the program.
Post-Award Conference

Post-Award Conference
The Contractor shall host a post-award conference within 30 calendar days of contract award at the Contractor’s facility. The purpose of the conference is to (1) achieve a clear and mutual understanding of all contract requirements, and (2) identify and resolve potential problems. The Contractor shall propose an agenda prior to the conference which addresses, discusses, and provides status on their understanding of the contract requirements. Conference minutes including action items shall be delivered 15 calendar days after the conference. (CDRL A006)
Induction Readiness Review

Induction Readiness Review
The Contractor shall host an aircraft induction readiness review within 30 calendar days prior to start of first aircraft modification. Review minutes including action items shall be delivered 15 calendar days after the review. (CDRL A007)
Progress Status Report
The Contractor shall provide monthly program status reports for the duration of the contract. The report shall be in Contractor’s format and as a minimum include highlights of progress against key milestones and risks or issues affecting the program. (CDRL A008) 
Quality

Quality
The Contractor shall provide and maintain a quality system that as a minimum adheres to the requirements of AS9100D for Quality Assurance in design, development, production, installation and servicing. The Contractor shall require of sub‐tier suppliers a quality system achieving control of the quality of the services and supplies provided.
The Contractor shall hold and maintain certification as a Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) approved Repair Station for performing aircraft maintenance and modifications. 
Security
The Contractor shall be responsible for the physical security of the modification aircraft and all FAC provided equipment, tools, and materials at the Contractor’s facility.
Over-and-Above

Over-and-Above
The Contractor shall submit over-and-above (O&A) requests for repair and replacement items outside the scope of this SOW. O&A requests shall be submitted per event and shall include specific effort, skills required, and hours required per skill. Each O&A work request must be approved in writing by the FAC representative before work is started.
Warranty
The Contractor shall provide warranty for workmanship on installation services equal to those offered to the general public, minimum of one year. The warranty will end on a date which coincides with the actual delivery date of each aircraft (e.g., if aircraft #1 is delivered on 18 Dec 2025, then the warranty will end on       18 Dec 2026).
DELIVERABLES

DELIVERABLES
The Contractor shall deliver the Contract Data Requirements List (CDRL) items shown in the table below. CDRL submissions shall be complete, thorough, accurate, technically acceptable, and in compliance with all requirements of this SOW.

ACRONYMS

Mission playback, storage, and export with forensic archival and retrieval.
Cabin Interphone
The Contractor shall upgrade the current cabin internal communication system (ICS) with a dual-net ICS capable of isolating mission cabin communications from cockpit with selectable integration with all intercom stations. The ICS shall interface with all legacy radios (e.g., HF, UHF, VHF, SATCOM).

metadata.summary: This document, dated 02/12/2024, is a Statement of Work (SOW) outlining the requirements set by the Fuerza Aèrea Colombiana (FAC), or Colombian Air Force, for the design, development, and installation of a modernized avionics suite as well as enhanced mission systems for their SR-560 Tracker aircraft. The contractor will modify five FAC SR-560 aircraft with upgraded cockpit avionics, mission computers, mission displays, and additional hardware, all of which will be installed according to the FAC-approved design. These adjustments will increase reliability, maintainability, and supportability of the aircraft. The design and development of the installation will be directed by a military handbook, while existing radar and camera systems must not affect the aircraft's center of gravity nor limit current performance. The document further details necessary specifications for the avionics, differing computer systems, and the mission display to facilitate understanding and compliance.

document.pageContent:
DESCRIPTION OF SERVICES
Purpose
This Statement of Work (SOW) defines the Contractor’s requirements for accomplishing the design, development, and installation of a modernized avionics suite and enhanced mission systems on Fuerza Aèrea Colombiana (FAC) SR-560 Tracker aircraft. The aircraft modification provides the FAC with an avionics upgrade and mission systems improvements that avoid overall shortcomings in reliability, maintainability, and supportability of the current equipment.
Program Objectives

metadata.summary: This document, dated 02/12/2024, is a Statement of Work (SOW) outlining the requirements set by the Fuerza Aèrea Colombiana (FAC), or Colombian Air Force, for the design, development, and installation of a modernized avionics suite as well as enhanced mission systems for their SR-560 Tracker aircraft. The contractor will modify five FAC SR-560 aircraft with upgraded cockpit avionics, mission computers, mission displays, and additional hardware, all of which will be installed according to the FAC-approved design. These adjustments will increase reliability, maintainability, and supportability of the aircraft. The design and development of the installation will be directed by a military handbook, while existing radar and camera systems must not affect the aircraft's center of gravity nor limit current performance. The document further details necessary specifications for the avionics, differing computer systems, and the mission display to facilitate understanding and compliance.

document.pageContent:
Over-and-Above
The Contractor shall submit over-and-above (O&A) requests for repair and replacement items outside the scope of this SOW. O&A requests shall be submitted per event and shall include specific effort, skills required, and hours required per skill. Each O&A work request must be approved in writing by the FAC representative before work is started.
Warranty
The Contractor shall provide warranty for workmanship on installation services equal to those offered to the general public, minimum of one year. The warranty will end on a date which coincides with the actual delivery date of each aircraft (e.g., if aircraft #1 is delivered on 18 Dec 2025, then the warranty will end on       18 Dec 2026).
DELIVERABLES

document.pageContent:
Program Planning and Control
The Contractor shall be responsible for planning and implementing oversight for the engineering design, development, and installation activities. The Contractor shall develop, maintain, and provide an Integrated Master Schedule (IMS) to the FAC representative. The IMS shall be updated monthly until completion of the aircraft installations. (CDRL A005)
Subcontractor Management
The Contractor shall manage their subcontractors in such a manner that schedule, cost, quality and performance problems are identified and resolved in a manner which avoids impact to the program.
Post-Award Conference

document.pageContent:
Quality
The Contractor shall provide and maintain a quality system that as a minimum adheres to the requirements of AS9100D for Quality Assurance in design, development, production, installation and servicing. The Contractor shall require of sub‐tier suppliers a quality system achieving control of the quality of the services and supplies provided.
The Contractor shall hold and maintain certification as a Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) approved Repair Station for performing aircraft maintenance and modifications. 
Security
The Contractor shall be responsible for the physical security of the modification aircraft and all FAC provided equipment, tools, and materials at the Contractor’s facility.
Over-and-Above

document.pageContent:
The Contractor shall ensure the mission computer meets the following minimum capabilities:
MIL-performance circular connectors.
Minimum of two 1000BaseT Ethernet ports with low-latency Time Sensitive Networking (TSN) support for real-time networking.
Minimum of three slots for PCIe mini-cards for add-on I/O (e.g., MIL-STD-1553 and ARINC429).
Minimum of 16GB DDR memory.
Minimum of 64GB on-board solid-state data storage.
MIL-STD-810 or DO-160 thermal, shock, vibration, altitude, and humidity qualified.
MIL-STD-461 or DO-160 EMI/EMC qualified.
Mission Display
The Contractor shall replace the current mission monitors with full-color, sunlight-readable, multi-functional display (MFD) that fits into the existing positions in the cockpit.

document.pageContent:
Post-Award Conference
The Contractor shall host a post-award conference within 30 calendar days of contract award at the Contractor’s facility. The purpose of the conference is to (1) achieve a clear and mutual understanding of all contract requirements, and (2) identify and resolve potential problems. The Contractor shall propose an agenda prior to the conference which addresses, discusses, and provides status on their understanding of the contract requirements. Conference minutes including action items shall be delivered 15 calendar days after the conference. (CDRL A006)
Induction Readiness Review

document.pageContent:
Equipment Disposal
The Contractor shall return to FAC all equipment items removed from the aircraft and not reinstalled with a tagged status condition of “As Is” or “Unknown”. Other removed materials (e.g., wiring, connectors, brackets) shall be condemned in place and discarded as scrap.
Program Management
The Contractor shall provide programmatic support for the modification program.
The Contractor shall identify and maintain a single POC (Program Manager) for all tasks required for the modification program. The Program Manager shall be responsible and shall have authority for the control and coordination of all work performed under the contract.
Program Planning and Control

Reference Documents
The documents shown below should be used as guidance.
U.S. Military Standards
Commerical Standards
Schedule
The design, development, and installations shall be in accordance with the agreed delivery schedule at the time of the contract award and any subsequent contract amendments. The Contractor shall ensure aircraft are inducted nose-to-tail with a seven-calendar day overlap unless otherwise specified in the approved schedule.
REQUIREMENTS
Engineering Design and Development
The Contractor shall design and develop an installation drawing package to integrate the modification equipment into the aircraft that complies with applicable airworthiness requirements as specified in MIL-HDBK-516C.

sections.Field Aerospace Overview: [Field Aerospace has 75-plus years of experience making ordinary aircraft extraordinary for commercial and military customers. We employ more than 400 personnel at five North American locations. As shown in Figure 1, we have corporate offices in Cincinnati, Ohio, professional services in Patuxent River, Maryland, and engineering and manufacturing facilities in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, Toronto and Calgary, Canada. Field Aerospace is poised and ready to meet any and all customer needs.]
sections.Capabilities Overview: [Field Aerospace is recognized as an industry leader in the design, integration, manufacture, installation, flight test, and certification of interior and exterior aircraft modifications; avionics upgrades; flight-line, intermediate, and depot-level maintenance. An award-winning avionics equipment dealer and authorized service center, we offer aviation-related logistics and program management office support; Intelligence, Surveillance, Reconnaissance (ISR) modifications for special-mission and maritime applications; large and small aircraft maintenance; and aerospace parts manufacturing and subassembly services. Field Aerospace has more than 300 Supplemental Type Certificates (STCs) on turboprop, jet, and rotorcraft in Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), Transport Canada (TC), European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA), and other foreign jurisdictions. We have direct experience on more than 38 aircraft and rotorcraft platforms including T-1A, T-6A (CT-156 Harvard II), Gulfstream GII, GIV, and G550; Bombardier Challenger, CL-215/415, and CRJ 200 and 700 (CL-604); Cessna Citation; Dash 8 100/200/300 and Q400; F-16, C-130, KC-135, KC-10, E-6B, E-9, B-1B, and C-26; Boeing 777 and 727; Lockheed L-1011; Embraer EMB120, BAE-146, and SAAB 340; King Air 200 and 350; Fokker 27, Shorts SD3-60 Sherpa, DeHavilland Dash 7, Viking Twin Otter, CASA 212, and Beechcraft B1900; and UH-1, Mi-17, Bell, and Airbus rotorcraft. From initial concept through design, production, integration, and continuing support, our professional, responsive, and innovative employees achieve our customers’ specific requirements while ensuring high standards of quality and reliability. Field Aerospace’s modification and maintenance centers in Oklahoma City and Toronto perform flight-line, intermediate, and depot maintenance; aircraft modifications and upgrades; integration, certification, training, logistics, and program management. Our capabilities include electronic data conversions, configuration management, maintenance and flight manuals, parts and wiring diagrams, and contractor logistics support, including supply chain and inventory management, warehousing, vendor qualification, and export compliance. With over 75 years of operation in the aerospace industry, Field Aerospace has grown to be a center of excellence for aircraft modifications and a world-renowned parts manufacturing company.]

1.1. CERTIFICATIONS.Certifications and Approvals: [List FAA, AS9100, ISO certifications and related details to Field's Quality Management System (QMS)]
