Field Aerospace will rigorously adhere to the agreed delivery schedule established at contract award and any subsequent amendments by implementing comprehensive project management and scheduling controls. Our approach integrates advanced project management software tools that enable real-time monitoring, tracking, and reporting of progress against the delivery milestones. This system facilitates proactive identification and mitigation of potential schedule risks, ensuring timely execution of design, development, and installation activities.

To maintain strict compliance with the nose-to-tail aircraft induction sequence and the mandated seven-calendar day overlap, Field Aerospace employs detailed induction planning protocols. These protocols include coordination meetings with all stakeholders, clear sequencing of aircraft processing, and continuous oversight by dedicated scheduling personnel. Our project managers conduct regular status reviews and adjust resource allocation dynamically to uphold the induction timeline, minimizing downtime and optimizing workflow continuity.

Field Aerospace’s quality management system is certified to AS9100D, reflecting our commitment to aerospace industry best practices and continuous improvement. Additionally, our FAA Part 145 Repair Station certification underscores our capability to perform maintenance, repair, and overhaul activities in compliance with stringent regulatory standards. These certifications support our disciplined approach to schedule adherence and quality assurance.

Through these integrated management practices, combined with our experienced personnel and robust communication channels, Field Aerospace ensures that all design, development, and installation efforts are executed on schedule and that aircraft induction strictly follows the nose-to-tail sequence with the required overlap, thereby meeting or exceeding contractual requirements.

[{"requirement":"The Contractor shall design and develop an installation drawing package complying with MIL-HDBK-516C airworthiness requirements.","section":"Engineering Design and Development","complianceMethod":"Develop detailed installation drawings that adhere to the standards and guidelines specified in MIL-HDBK-516C to ensure airworthiness compliance.","response":"Field Aerospace will develop comprehensive installation drawing packages that fully comply with the airworthiness requirements outlined in MIL-HDBK-516C. Our engineering team employs advanced CAD tools such as SolidWorks and CATIA to create precise, detailed drawings that meet or exceed the standards for airworthiness certification. We integrate MIL-HDBK-516C criteria early in the design phase to ensure all structural, system integration, and safety considerations are addressed. Our process includes rigorous internal reviews and validation against MIL-HDBK-516C guidelines, ensuring that installation drawings provide clear, unambiguous instructions for manufacturing and assembly. Field Aerospace holds AS9100D certification and operates FAA Part 145 Repair Station facilities, underscoring our commitment to quality and regulatory compliance. Additionally, our engineers collaborate closely with certification authorities and utilize established engineering data requirements agreements to support the airworthiness review process. This approach guarantees that the installation drawings not only comply with MIL-HDBK-516C but also facilitate efficient certification and maintainability of the aircraft modifications. Through these practices, Field Aerospace ensures that all installation drawing packages support safe, reliable, and certified aircraft modifications in accordance with military and federal aviation standards." ,"priority":"High"}]

Field Aerospace will ensure that all modification equipment is designed, tested, and validated to maintain and not degrade the current aircraft and mission performance capabilities. Utilizing advanced engineering tools such as SolidWorks for detailed CAD modeling, Field Aerospace conducts rigorous compatibility assessments with existing systems, specifically the AN/APG-66 radar and FLIR surveillance camera. These assessments include electromagnetic interference (EMI) testing and system integration evaluations to confirm seamless operation alongside legacy avionics.

Performance testing is conducted in accordance with recognized aerospace standards, including FAA Advisory Circulars and MIL-STD-810G environmental testing protocols, to simulate operational conditions and verify that modifications do not impair aircraft functionality or mission effectiveness. Thermal cycle testing, vibration analysis, and functional system checks are integral to the validation process, ensuring durability and reliability under all expected flight conditions.

Field Aerospace holds AS9100D certification and operates as an FAA Part 145 Repair Station, underscoring its commitment to quality and regulatory compliance. The company’s experienced engineering and quality assurance teams implement a structured verification and validation process, documenting all test results and corrective actions to maintain traceability and accountability.

Through these comprehensive engineering design, testing, and validation practices, Field Aerospace guarantees that modification equipment will be fully compatible with the AN/APG-66 radar and FLIR surveillance camera systems, preserving the aircraft’s operational capabilities and mission readiness without compromise.

Field Aerospace will execute the integration of updated cockpit displays by transitioning from legacy CRT technology to advanced LCD displays, ensuring enhanced clarity, reliability, and operational efficiency. This process involves meticulous hardware and software integration, where LCD units are installed and interfaced with existing avionics systems. Digital airport charts, approach charts, and integrated 2D maps encompassing flight plans, weather data, traffic information, and geographical boundaries will be incorporated into the cockpit display system to provide comprehensive situational awareness to flight crews.

Our approach adheres strictly to applicable aerospace standards, including FAA Advisory Circulars (ACs) relevant to avionics modifications and MIL-STD-810G for environmental testing, ensuring the durability and performance of installed components under operational conditions. Field Aerospace leverages its AS9100D certified quality management system and FAA Part 145 Repair Station certification to maintain rigorous quality control and compliance throughout the integration process.

Utilizing advanced engineering tools such as SolidWorks for detailed CAD modeling and system design, we ensure precise fit and function of hardware components. The software integration phase includes rigorous validation and verification procedures to confirm accurate rendering and real-time updating of digital charts and maps. Comprehensive system testing encompasses functional tests, electromagnetic interference (EMI) assessments, and thermal cycle testing to validate system robustness and reliability.

Field Aerospace’s experienced engineering and avionics teams coordinate closely with stakeholders to tailor the integration to specific aircraft configurations and mission requirements. Post-installation, we conduct thorough acceptance testing and provide detailed documentation, including updated maintenance manuals and operational procedures, to support continued airworthiness and operational readiness. This methodical and standards-driven approach guarantees that the upgraded cockpit displays meet or exceed all regulatory and performance requirements, delivering a state-of-the-art avionics solution.

[{
  "requirement": "The Contractor shall replace the current mission computer with an ultra-small form factor rugged computer capable of low-power (< 25W) operation with 28 VDC input power.",
  "section": "Mission Computer",
  "complianceMethod": "Select and install a rugged, ultra-small form factor computer that meets the low-power (< 25W) and 28 VDC input power requirements, then verify compliance through testing and validation.",

4.1 Organizational Structure.4.1.1 Subcontractor and Teaming Arrangem: Field Aerospace employs a comprehensive subcontractor management approach to ensure schedule, cost, quality, and performance requirements are consistently met. Subcontractors are selected based on qualifications and past performance, with contract requirements flowed down to ensure compliance. Subcontractor activities are integrated into the overall program schedule and budget, monitored through AS9100D-compliant quality management systems, regular audits, inspections, and performance reviews. Earned Value Management (EVM) techniques track cost and schedule adherence. Communication is maintained through regular status meetings and reporting, enabling early identification and mitigation of risks. Configuration control and documentation protocols ensure subcontractor deliverables meet technical and contractual standards. The Program Manager serves as the single point of contact for subcontractor coordination, facilitating timely resolution of issues and maintaining alignment with program milestones and budgets. This approach ensures successful program execution and customer satisfaction.
4.1 Organizational Structure.4.1.2 Methods and Lines of Communication: Field Aerospace establishes clear and structured communication lines within the program governance framework. The Program Manager acts as the central point of contact, coordinating all internal and external communications. Regular program status meetings, teleconferences, and written reports ensure transparent and timely information flow among engineering, production, quality assurance, subcontractors, and the customer. Communication protocols are defined in the Program Management Plan (PMP), including escalation paths for risk and issue management. Collaboration tools such as Microsoft Teams and SharePoint facilitate document sharing and real-time communication. This structured communication approach supports effective decision-making, risk mitigation, and program alignment.
4.1 Organizational Structure.4.1.3 Planning, Implementing, Tracking a: Field Aerospace utilizes a hybrid project management methodology combining Waterfall and Agile principles tailored to aerospace program requirements. Planning is conducted using ISO 9001 and AS9100D compliant processes, with detailed Work Breakdown Structures (WBS) and Integrated Master Schedules (IMS) developed in Microsoft Project. Implementation follows phased execution with iterative reviews and risk assessments. Progress is tracked through Earned Value Management (EVM) metrics and Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) monitored via Power BI dashboards. Control mechanisms include configuration management, quality audits, and risk mitigation plans with defined escalation procedures. Regular management reviews ensure alignment with schedule, cost, and quality objectives, enabling proactive adjustments to maintain program health.

4.3 Project Management Organization.4.3.1 Task Organization Chart: Field Aerospace will develop a detailed task organization chart delineating roles and responsibilities across program management, engineering, quality assurance, production, procurement, and subcontractor oversight. The chart will illustrate reporting lines, interfaces with the customer and subcontractors, and key decision authorities. This organizational structure supports efficient coordination and accountability throughout the program lifecycle.
4.3 Project Management Organization.4.3.2 Subcontractor Management: Subcontractor management is integrated within the program management framework, with dedicated personnel overseeing subcontractor performance, compliance, and integration. Field Aerospace enforces strict flow-down of contract requirements, quality standards, and schedule commitments. Regular audits, performance reviews, and risk assessments are conducted to ensure subcontractor deliverables meet program expectations. The Program Manager maintains direct communication with subcontractor leads to address issues promptly and coordinate corrective actions, ensuring seamless integration of subcontracted work into the overall program.
4.3 Project Management Organization.4.3.3 Project Management Authority: The Program Manager holds full authority and responsibility for the control and coordination of all contract work, including technical, schedule, cost, and quality aspects. Authority limitations and role conflicts are managed through clearly defined delegation of authority documented in the Program Management Plan. The Program Manager is empowered to approve purchases, subcontractor engagements, and resource allocations within contract scope and budget. Conflicts of interest are mitigated through organizational separation of duties and adherence to ethical standards. This governance ensures decisive leadership and accountability for successful program execution.

4.4 MANAGEMENT PLANS – PROJECT MANAGEMEN.4.4.1 Time-phased summary schedule of wo: Field Aerospace will develop a comprehensive time-phased summary schedule detailing all major work efforts, milestones, and deliverables. The schedule will be structured as an Integrated Master Schedule (IMS) incorporating design, development, procurement, installation, testing, and certification activities. The IMS will be maintained and updated monthly, providing visibility into progress and enabling proactive management of critical path tasks. Scheduling tools such as Microsoft Project will be utilized, supported by Power BI for real-time status visualization. The schedule will incorporate the required nose-to-tail aircraft induction sequence with a seven-calendar day overlap, ensuring efficient resource utilization and minimal downtime.
4.4 MANAGEMENT PLANS – PROJECT MANAGEMEN.4.4.2 System Used to Establish, Control,: Field Aerospace employs Microsoft Project as the primary scheduling tool to establish, control, and monitor program schedules. The IMS is developed with detailed task dependencies, resource assignments, and milestone tracking. Schedule performance is monitored through Earned Value Management (EVM) metrics and regular status updates. Power BI dashboards provide program leadership and stakeholders with real-time schedule health indicators, enabling timely identification of variances and corrective actions. Change control processes govern schedule modifications, ensuring alignment with contract requirements and customer approval.
4.4 MANAGEMENT PLANS – PROJECT MANAGEMEN.4.4.3 Cost Data Management: Cost data management is integrated within Field Aerospace’s Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system, enabling accurate tracking of labor, materials, subcontractor costs, and overhead. Cost performance is monitored through Earned Value Management (EVM) techniques, linking cost data with schedule progress to assess program health. Regular cost reports are generated and reviewed by program management to identify variances and implement corrective measures. Configuration management ensures cost data integrity, and all financial transactions comply with contractual and regulatory requirements. This approach supports transparent and effective cost control throughout the program.
4.4 MANAGEMENT PLANS – PROJECT MANAGEMEN.4.4.4 Review Requirements: Field Aerospace implements a structured review process encompassing design reviews, milestone assessments, quality audits, and risk management reviews. Reviews are scheduled in alignment with the Integrated Master Schedule and documented in the Program Management Plan. Key stakeholders, including customer representatives and subcontractors, participate in reviews to ensure comprehensive oversight. Action items from reviews are tracked to closure using project management tools, supporting continuous improvement and risk mitigation. This disciplined review process ensures program alignment with technical, schedule, and quality objectives.
4.4 MANAGEMENT PLANS – PROJECT MANAGEMEN.4.4.5 Identification of Major Risk Areas: Major risk areas are identified through a formal risk management process integrated into the Program Management Plan. Risks related to schedule delays, technical challenges, subcontractor performance, regulatory compliance, and resource availability are continuously assessed. A risk register is maintained and reviewed weekly, with mitigation strategies developed and implemented for high-priority risks. Escalation procedures are defined to promptly address emerging issues. Field Aerospace’s quality management system and extensive experience in aerospace modifications support effective risk identification and management, minimizing program impacts and ensuring successful delivery.

sections.Estimation Methodology: Field Aerospace employs a rigorous and structured cost estimation methodology grounded in aerospace industry best practices and standards. Our approach integrates detailed Work Breakdown Structures (WBS) and Integrated Master Schedules (IMS) to capture all design, development, installation, and testing activities. Cost estimates are developed using historical data from over 300 Supplemental Type Certificates (STCs) and multiple aircraft platform modifications, ensuring accuracy and relevance. We apply risk-adjusted cost modeling to account for uncertainties and potential schedule impacts, leveraging Earned Value Management (EVM) techniques for ongoing cost control. Our methodology includes comprehensive labor, material, subcontractor, and overhead cost assessments, aligned with AS9100D quality management system requirements and FAA Part 145 Repair Station standards. All cost inputs are validated through cross-functional reviews involving engineering, program management, and finance teams to ensure realism and completeness. This disciplined approach supports transparent, auditable, and defensible cost proposals that meet customer and regulatory expectations.
Risk Assumptions: Schedule adherence assumes aircraft induction will follow a nose-to-tail sequence with a seven-calendar day overlap, as specified in the contract, to optimize resource utilization and minimize downtime.

Subcontractor performance and delivery will meet established quality and schedule requirements, supported by rigorous oversight and compliance with AS9100D and FAR 52.245-1 property management clauses.

No significant deviations from approved installation drawings, technical data, or regulatory requirements will occur during design, development, and installation phases, ensuring predictable cost and schedule outcomes.

Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) parts relevant to contract administration, quality assurance, and reporting requirements.

FAA regulations including 14 CFR Part 145 for Repair Station certification, FAA Advisory Circulars (ACs) such as AC 43.13-1B for maintenance and alterations, and MIL-HDBK-516C for airworthiness standards.
sections.Cost Realism and Audit Readiness: Field Aerospace ensures cost realism through the use of validated historical data, detailed labor and material cost breakdowns, and risk-adjusted estimates reflecting current market conditions and program-specific factors. Our cost proposal is fully auditable, supported by comprehensive documentation including basis of estimate narratives, subcontractor quotes, and internal cost control records. We maintain strict configuration management and quality assurance processes compliant with AS9100D and ISO 10012 standards, facilitating traceability and transparency. Our FAA Part 145 Repair Station certification and Organization Designation Authorization (ODA) for STC approvals further demonstrate our commitment to regulatory compliance and quality. All cost data is prepared and reviewed by qualified personnel with aerospace program management expertise, ensuring defensibility and alignment with customer expectations. This approach supports effective audit readiness and confidence in the proposed costs.

technicalProposal.submissionFormat: PDF submission with Times New Roman, 12 pt font, 1-inch margins, double spacing

Engineering Design and Development.Installation Drawing Package: Field Aerospace employs a rigorous design and development process for the installation drawing package to integrate modification equipment into the FAC SR-560 Tracker aircraft, ensuring full compliance with MIL-HDBK-516C airworthiness requirements. Utilizing advanced CAD tools such as SolidWorks and CATIA, our engineering team develops detailed installation drawings covering structural, electrical, and system interfaces. The process includes structured Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) and Integrated Master Schedule (IMS) management, in-process inspections, and documentation controls compliant with AS9100D and ISO 10012 standards. Coordination with certification authorities ensures validation of compliance and continued airworthiness post-modification. Our extensive experience with over 300 Supplemental Type Certificates (STCs) across multiple aircraft platforms underpins our capability to deliver certified, high-quality installation packages.
Engineering Design and Development.Compatibility with Existing Systems: Field Aerospace ensures that modification equipment does not degrade current aircraft and mission performance capabilities. Detailed engineering analyses including structural, aerodynamic, electrical load, and system integration assessments confirm compatibility with existing systems such as the AN/APG-66 radar and FLIR surveillance camera. Compliance with FAA and Transport Canada certification requirements, including Part 25 regulations, is maintained. Configuration control and rigorous ground and flight testing validate that modifications do not impair radar or sensor functionality or aircraft operational capabilities. Documentation includes substantiation reports, test results, and updated maintenance manuals to support continued airworthiness and mission readiness.
Engineering Design and Development.Center of Gravity (CG) Management: Modification equipment configurations are engineered to avoid adverse effects on the aircraft's center of gravity. Detailed weight and balance analyses are conducted throughout the design phase, accounting for added, removed, or relocated equipment and structural components. Equipment placement is optimized to maintain safe CG limits within OEM performance parameters. Certified inspectors and precise measurement tools update weight and balance data, ensuring compliance with AS9100D and FAA requirements. Updated weight and balance reports and certification packages document compliance, supported by Field Aerospace's extensive STC experience.
Engineering Design and Development.Continuous Functionality Across Environm: Field Aerospace conducts rigorous testing and validation to ensure modification equipment functions continuously throughout the full environmental and operational range per the approved flight manual. Testing includes system requirements analysis, structural and thermal analyses (FEA), classical stress analysis, and damage tolerance assessments. Compliance with FAA regulations and Supplemental Type Certificates (STCs) is ensured. Test plans encompass power and cooling tests, environmental control system evaluations, and functional checks. Quality management systems certified to AS9100D and ISO 9001:2015 standards govern the process, with detailed documentation supporting continuous airworthiness and operational performance.

Cockpit Avionics.Pilot Displays: Replacement of current pilot displays with high-resolution picture displays that are brighter, clearer, and run cooler is executed using advanced backlight technologies and thermal management solutions. Integration ensures compatibility with existing cockpit avionics architecture and FAA certification requirements. Rigorous testing validates enhanced visibility and cooler operation under various lighting conditions. Documentation includes complete technical data packages and certification documentation to support airworthiness approvals.
Cockpit Avionics.Updated Cockpit Displays and Chart Integ: Integration of updated cockpit displays with airport charts, approach charts, and integrated map features enhances flight safety by improving situational awareness. Advanced glass cockpit flight information display systems combine synthetic vision, advanced mapping, weather, terrain, and traffic awareness. Compliance with AS9100D and ISO 10012 standards is maintained. Certification steps include FAA Part 25 compliance and Supplemental Type Certificate (STC) acquisition. Comprehensive documentation and thorough testing ensure reliable operation.

Mission Computer.Replacement Specifications: The replacement mission computer features an ultra-small form factor rugged design with low power consumption (<25W) and 28 VDC input power. It includes MIL-performance circular connectors, minimum two 1000BaseT Ethernet ports with TSN support, minimum three PCIe mini-card slots, minimum 16GB DDR memory, and minimum 64GB solid-state storage. The system meets MIL-STD-810, DO-160, and MIL-STD-461 environmental and EMI qualifications. Comprehensive testing and certification ensure compliance and operational reliability.

Mission Display.Replacement Monitors: Current mission monitors are replaced with full-color, sunlight-readable multi-function displays (MFDs) compatible with existing cockpit positions. Integration with Honeywell Primus avionics suite and support for mission system video inputs are ensured. Testing includes environmental and EMI assessments. Documentation and configuration control support certification and maintenance.

Mission Console / Workstation.Monitors: Full-color, sunlight-readable mission console monitors with MIL-performance circular connectors, 16:9 aspect ratio, 1000:1 contrast ratio, minimum 1920x1080 resolution, 28 VDC input power, and <90W power draw are installed. Inputs include composite video, DisplayPort, HDMI, and VGA. Features include on-screen display controls, dimmable functionality, and anti-reflective coating. Compliance with MIL-STD-810, DO-160, and MIL-STD-461 EMI/EMC standards is verified through testing.
Mission Console / Workstation.Keyboard and Control Grip: The mission keyboard is replaced with a ruggedized 1U keyboard with integrated track ball or touch pad, meeting MIL-STD-810 and DO-160 environmental standards. The control grip is replaced with an ergonomic cobra-style grip featuring six programmable functions, compliant with MIL-STD-810 and DO-160. Installation includes rigorous testing and certification.

Engineering Design and Development.Mission Software: Upgraded integrated sensor control and image analysis software provides enhanced mission functionality between APG-66 radar and EO/IR turret, including mission playback, storage, export, and forensic archival and retrieval. Software development follows AS9100D quality standards and FAA Part 145 Repair Station certifications. Testing includes unit, integration, system, and acceptance testing aligned with MIL-STD-810G environmental standards. Secure data management practices ensure data integrity and confidentiality.
Engineering Design and Development.Cabin Interphone: The cabin internal communication system is upgraded to a dual-net ICS isolating mission cabin communications from the cockpit, with selectable integration and interface with all legacy radios. The system includes mission Audio Management Units (AMUs), isolate functions, individual ICS control panels, and essential DC bus power. Compliance with FAA regulations and MIL-STD-810G environmental standards is ensured through rigorous testing.
Engineering Design and Development.Video Recorder: Current Digital Video Recorders (DVRs) are replaced with advanced solid-state DVRs capable of multi-channel 1080p color video and audio recording, integration with radar and sensor inputs, removable solid-state storage, lighter weight, and 28 VDC power input. Installation and certification follow AS9100D and FAA Part 145 Repair Station standards, with comprehensive testing and documentation.
Engineering Design and Development.FLIR System: The FLIR system is upgraded to the 380 HDX configuration, incorporating advanced image aiding, improved targeting, and enhanced performance capabilities. The upgrade follows rigorous engineering design, integration, and testing protocols compliant with FAA certification standards and MIL-STD-810G environmental testing. Documentation supports FAA Supplemental Type Certificate (STC) approval.
Engineering Design and Development.Revision of Technical Data: Field Aerospace implements a rigorous process for updating aircraft flight, inspection, wiring, and maintenance manuals to reflect modifications. Configuration management complies with ANSI/EIA-649-1998 and ISO 10007 standards. A Configuration Control Board oversees changes, ensuring traceability and accuracy. Revised manuals are delivered electronically with executive summaries highlighting key changes.
Engineering Design and Development.Aircraft Modification: Modifications including installation of Group A-Kit, Group B-Kit, and software are performed strictly per approved installation drawings and manuals. Compliance with FAA Advisory Circulars and MIL-STD-810G standards is maintained. Configuration management and inspection protocols ensure quality and conformity. Facilities provide adequate ramp and hangar space with protection against severe weather.
Engineering Design and Development.Aircraft Records: All modification efforts and deficiencies are meticulously recorded in aircraft documentation, coordinated with FAC representatives for discrepancy resolution. Work records are transcribed into FAC aircraft record documents (CDRL A002). A comprehensive list of logbook entries carried forward is provided prior to aircraft acceptance (CDRL A003).
Engineering Design and Development.Inspections: Incoming overall condition inspections are performed jointly with FAC representatives, with documented results provided within 7 calendar days (CDRL A004). Acceptance inspections are facilitated post-installation checkout and acceptance check flight, ensuring compliance and readiness.
Engineering Design and Development.Acceptance Check Flight: Field Aerospace supports FAC aircrew during acceptance check flights by providing qualified personnel and maintenance crew support. Coordination ensures all resources and documentation are available to facilitate safe and effective flight operations.
Engineering Design and Development.Equipment Disposal: Removed equipment is returned to FAC with appropriate tagging ('As Is' or 'Unknown'). Other materials are condemned and discarded as scrap following documented procedures compliant with AS9100D and FAA Part 145 standards. Hazardous materials are managed per environmental regulations.
Engineering Design and Development.Program Management: A dedicated Program Manager serves as the single point of contact with full authority for contract control and coordination. The Program Management Office employs PMI-certified professionals and integrated program teams to oversee planning, execution, risk management, and communication. Regular status reporting and risk assessments ensure transparency and alignment.
Engineering Design and Development.Program Planning and Control: Oversight of engineering design, development, and installation activities is planned and implemented with adherence to AS9100D and ISO 10012 standards. An Integrated Master Schedule (IMS) is developed, maintained, and updated monthly (CDRL A005), providing detailed task tracking and milestone management.
Engineering Design and Development.Subcontractor Management: Subcontractors are managed through rigorous selection, flow-down of contract requirements, quality monitoring, earned value management, and regular communication. Compliance with FAR 52.245-1 and AS9100D standards is enforced. Risk mitigation and corrective actions are integral to subcontractor oversight.
Engineering Design and Development.Post-Award Conference: Field Aerospace conducts a post-award conference within 30 calendar days of contract award, with a comprehensive agenda addressing contract requirements. Conference minutes with action items are delivered within 15 calendar days (CDRL A006), supporting clear communication and issue resolution.
Engineering Design and Development.Induction Readiness Review: An aircraft induction readiness review is hosted within 30 calendar days prior to first aircraft modification, involving all stakeholders. Review minutes and action items are delivered within 15 calendar days (CDRL A007), ensuring readiness and accountability.
Engineering Design and Development.Progress Status Report: Monthly program status reports are provided throughout the contract, detailing progress against milestones, risks, and issues (CDRL A008). Reports are reviewed and approved by program management, facilitating informed decision-making and proactive management.
Engineering Design and Development.Quality: Field Aerospace maintains a quality management system certified to AS9100D, ensuring rigorous quality assurance in design, development, production, installation, and servicing. Sub-tier suppliers are required to maintain equivalent quality systems. The company holds FAA Part 145 Repair Station certification, supporting compliance with regulatory requirements.
Engineering Design and Development.Security: Physical security measures at Field Aerospace facilities include controlled access, surveillance systems, secure storage, and personnel training to protect modification aircraft and FAC-provided equipment, tools, and materials. Compliance with FAA Advisory Circulars and MIL-STD-810G standards is maintained.
Engineering Design and Development.Over-and-Above: A formal process for submitting over-and-above (O&A) requests is implemented, detailing effort, skills, and hours required per event. FAC approval is obtained prior to commencement of any O&A work, ensuring contract compliance and effective change management.
Engineering Design and Development.Warranty: Field Aerospace provides a workmanship warranty on installation services for a minimum of one year from the delivery date. Warranty terms include prompt correction of workmanship defects at no additional cost. Quality assurance processes and documentation support warranty claims, reflecting commitment to customer satisfaction and reliability.

pastPerformance.description: Performed modifications on Bombardier Series DHC-8-200 and DHC-8-300 aircraft including installation of new EO/IR sensor provisions, upgrade to ARC-210 provisions, integration of new TCAS 7.1 system with TTR-2100, digital glass cockpit upgrade, supplemental cooling system installation, mission power modifications, replacement of baggage bins and addition of handrails (Q300 only), removal of above floor air filter (Q300 only), and installation of pilot/co-pilot cockpit displays. Work included obtaining FAA approvals, maintaining STCs, providing installation drawings and documentation, conducting inspections and testing, and delivering aircraft in safe for flight condition.

Modification includes relocation or deletion of existing nose bay avionics equipment to accommodate Microwave Power Module (MPM), manufacturing and installation of radomes, and ensuring aircraft can be returned to Standard Transport Category after removal of new radar systems.
